page.title: 11Local History: Archaeology
page.content: Walking across the Downs there is plenty of evidence to indicate that the area has been settled and cultivated for thousands of years. Tumuli and lynchets of iron age field systems can be seen. Recent archaeological work (1976) at Bullock Down have discovered flint tools dating back to 4000BC. Settlemant and cultivation of the land came 1000yrs later and although the earliest evidence of man goes back to 4000BC, the area has only ever been sparsely populated. However, increase in demand for corn in Roman times led to a group of families settling. During the Middle Ages the farmstead at Kiln Combe was probably from Birling Manor. In the sixteenth century profits from wool led to much of the land being turned to sheep pasture and redundancy of labourers.
